chapter.title: PropertySheet and Control Dialogs
chapter.para: A Windows property sheet is a main window containing one or more overlapping windows. Each of the overlapping windows is called a page. The main window is called a property sheet, signifying a property sheet is used to set properties. In practice programmers use property sheets for a number of different reasons other than setting properties.
ooDialog implements property sheets through the PropertySheetDialog and the PropertySheetPage classes.

Windows has a style for dialogs that allows the dialog to work well as a dialog within a top-level dialog. The ooDialog framework has support for this type of dialog and calls them control dialogs because they function like a control within the top-level dialog. These dialogs work well as the content for tab control pages. The implementation for control dialogs is primarily through the ControlDialog class. The TabOwnerDialog and its helper classes provide a way for programmers to use ControlDialog objects in their tab controls without having to manage all the minute details themselves.

section.title: PropertySheetDialog Class
section.para: The Windows property sheet is a dialog that contains one or more overlapping child windows called pages. Each page normally contains a group of related dialog controls. Each page has a tab that the user can select to bring the page to the foreground of the property sheet. The main dialog itself is the property sheet. The name property sheet indicates that Microsoft's original purpose for the property sheet was to set properties. However, property sheet dialogs are useful in any situation where the programmer needs to place a number of dialog controls without using a huge dialog. In practice, programmers have not restricted the use of property sheet dialogs to strictly setting properties.

There is a special type of property sheet called a wizard. Wizards are designed to show the pages one at a time in a sequence that is controlled by the application. Instead of selecting from a group of pages by clicking a tab, users navigate forward and backward through the sequence, one page at a time, by clicking Next or Back buttons located at the bottom of the wizard.

The ooDialog framework provides the PropertySheetDialog and PropertySheetPage classes that allow the programmer to create property sheet and wizard dialogs. Unlike most other ooDialog dialogs, the operating system manages much of the property sheet dialog itself. For instance, the operating system executes and shows the page dialogs itself. The ooDialog programmer does not invoke the execute method for the page dialogs.

row.entry: The maximun number of pages a property sheet dialog can have. This is an operating system restriction.

section.title: Control Dialogs
section.para: Windows supports a style for dialogs that allow the dialog to work well as a dialog within a top-level dialog. In essence a dialog with this style functions as a dialog control within the top-level dialog.

section.title: initializing (Attribute)
section.para: The initializing attribute reflects the status of the initialization of the underlying Windows dialog. The value of the attribute is .true prior to the creation of the underlying dialog and up to the point that the underlying dialog has finished its initialization. From that point on, its value is .false.

listitem.para: The initializing attribute returns .true until the Windows dialog has completed its initialization. Afterwards, the attribute will always return .false
The ooDialog framework sets the initializing attribute internally to reflect the state of the Windows dialog's initialization.
Raises syntax errors when incorrect arguments are detected.

section.title: TabOwnerDialog Class
section.para: A tab owner dialog is a convenience dialog used to manage tab controls that use control dialogs as the pages of the tab. It relieves the Rexx programmer of most of the burden of sizing, positioning, showing, hiding, and notifying the page dialogs used for the tab control(s) in the top-level dialog. It is a mixin class that can be inherited by any type of top-level ooDialog dialog class.

A dialog subclass that inherits the TabOwnerDialog class is very similar to a PropertySheetDialog. However, unlike the PropertySheetDialog, a tab owner dialog is controled by the ooDialog framework. This makes it somewhat more flexible than a property sheet dialog, which is controled by the operating system

section.title: tabOwnerSetActive
section.para: The SETACTIVE event notification informs a dialog that the page dialog of a tab is about to be activated. By default, the notification is sent to the page dialog itself. However, the Rexx programmer can specify that the notification be sent to the tab owner dialog instead.

listitem.para: Raises syntax errors when incorrect arguments are detected.
